text: Barack Obama ran an extremely
disciplined campaign for the presidency
and he's run a disciplined transition in
advance of his inauguration next month
but part of the challenge of his new job
is events that no president can control
one of them came last month with a
terror attacks in India another came
today with the arrest of Illinois
governor Rod Blagojevich on allegations
that Blagojevich tried to sell the
Senate seat Obama has given up to become
president governor Blagojevich has been
arrested in the middle of what we could
only describe as a political corruption
crime spirit spree US attorney patrick
fitzgerald alleged that boo gorvich who
ran on a platform of reform to succeed a
Republican who's now in jail on
corruption charges explored the
financial benefits that he could get in
exchange for appointing different
politicians to replace Obama he was
released from custody on his own
recognizance in order to surrender his
passport this afternoon prosecutors are
making no linkage whatsoever between
Obama and Blagojevich's actions and the
president-elect said they had no contact
on the appointment but the sensational
story created a distraction that
overshadowed Obama's meeting with a
former Vice President Al Gore today and
it embarrasses the world of Illinois
Democrats just as it's preparing to
celebrate the final act of Obama's rise
from community organizer in Chicago to
Illinois State Senate to the US Senate
and soon to the White House Senator Dick
Durbin of Illinois who's close to Obama
sought to short-circuit one of the
pitfalls today by calling on the
Illinois legislature to remove the
appointment power from the governor's
hands by ordering a special Senate
election but the commotion in Obama's
backyard will continue as long as
governor Blagojevich remains in office
even as leaders in both parties begin
pressing for his resignation I'm John
Harwood chief Washington correspondent
for CNBC
